ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: An amazing overview of the performing arts in Russia at an incredibly important political time. This semester largely focused on Theater, but also had no shortage of Ballet and Opera.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It's very self-motivated - you're never tested on the material, so you really get out what you put in. Papers are pretty much completely freeform i.e. you choose your own topic. advice for undergrads: write two shorter papers rather than one long one. I know you won't, but I made this same mistake and feel morally obliged to give you a heads up.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Slides/visual stimuli almost always helped the presentations. I wish there'd have been a bit more discussion. It also would've been useful to have some form of textbook/historical context readings, rather than putting all of that information sped through in lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to a student that wants to develop their knowledge of 20th-century Russian performing arts. This course might be good for a student who speaks Russian or has a basic understanding of Russian history but is accessible to those who don't as well. This course is interesting but low intensity and made for a good fifth course.

If you are interested in highly political theater, yes. If you are a strong independent worker, yes. If you are interested in Russia, yes. If none of those things apply to you, I would not recommend it.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Usually a lecture/presentation with discussion at the end.

extras.title:
